item.title: If managers were angels
item.description:
â€œIf managers were angels, no upward management would be necessary. In a career administered by people over people, the great difficulty lies in this: a manager must be allowed to manage the managed; and in the next place, the managed must, in turn, also manage upwards.â€

â€” James â€œUncâ€ Madison, ex-VP BigCo, 3x Founder, Board Director, Executive Coach, Author of Jimâ€™s Federalist Newsletter

Alleigh refills her mug; her fifth coffee today. Itâ€™s been a rough week. She checks her phone to confirm the room: 3:00pm - 1:1 Sherry/Allie - Conf. Room Blackpink

Blackpink? Thatâ€™s the fishbowl next to Stray Kids. When Alleigh started at BigCo six months ago, K-pop conference room names seemed pretty lit. Now when she hears Pink Venom she thinks of sprint planning meetings.

Alleigh finds her room, Sherry isnâ€™t there yet; good, she has a few minutes to plan what she wants to say. This will be the third “biweekly” 1:1 Alleigh has had with Sherry. Is she allowed to complain in these meetings? Should she give updates? Or make small talk?

â€œsry running 15 mins lateâ€ â€” sher

Alleighâ€™s supposed to be increasing the shininess of the checkout button by fifteen percent. Why why why was she given this stupid task? She wants to build AI models, not mess around with button pixels like some front-end dev.

Sherry, the team’s manager, has been pushing everyone to log more PAT hours. PAT is BigCo’s internal agentic LLM coding tool that gets hyped at every all-hands. PAT is worse than no help though. So far, itâ€™s made the button: 1) purple, 2) disappear, 3) made another checkout button, and 4) tried to delete the entire checkout page. Alleigh canâ€™t find Dave anywhere. Dave is supposedly her mentor â€“ or wait is it her â€œonboarding buddyâ€. But heâ€™s never in the office; Dave is wherever Dave goes.

â€œneed to cancel. meeting ran over. anything important you needed to cover?â€ â€” sher

Big surprise. Important? What does important even mean? Alleigh gets another coffee and readies herself for another late night to make this godawful button shiny.

Alleigh’s supposed to be a rockstar. That’s what everyone told her. Or as her mom would say, “You’re just so good at this computer stuff.” She graduated in under four years, got straight As (well, nearly, she got a B in bowlingğŸ’€), all while working at Baby Gap.

When she started at BigCo, Alleigh imagined that through grit and hard workâ€”are those the same thing?â€”she’d quickly rise in the ranks. Instead, she’s spinning half the time.

During sprint planning last week, she was excited to take on the button shininess task. It was an urgent request from the VP of Product. She’d never touched that area of the code, but hey, she’d taken a web development class.

Originally, Sherry tried to assign it to Sammi, but Sammi, being Sammi, sandbagged the estimate and said three story points. Alleigh raised her hand and said she could do it in one. She didn’t even want the taskâ€”the churn detection ML saga looked way more interestingâ€”but she felt like such a hero taking one for the team. Sammi was all too quick to let her. Sammi then convinced Sherry to let her work on some devops taskâ€”blah, blah, blah. Alleigh didn’t care. It sounded boring.

Alleigh expected there to be some constant like checkout_button_shininess that she could just change. Or some CSS somewhere with a shininess style. Instead, there’s nothing. The checkout button magically materializes on the page, in all its too-matte glory, without even being summoned by mortal coders. God, she’s losing it.

Is this important? Or will Sherry think Alleigh’s incompetent and regret hiring her if she asks for help?

This is Sherry’s second year as a manager. She was the team’s tech lead before, and when the old manager left, she asked the director if she could have a shot at it.

As a tech lead, things were so much simpler. Refactoring systems, reducing latency, building elegant UI component architectures. She could get in the zone for hours solving complex problems and she was celebrated for it.

Now executive leadership has her tracking “PAT hours”â€”twenty to thirty per team member per week, a 50% QoQ improvement. Sherry knows it’s ridiculous. But as her dad used to say, “You can’t fight city hall.”

She’s worried about Dave. They started at BigCo around the same time, and he was her lifeline in those early days. Something’s off with him lately. He isnâ€™t himself anymore. Sherry suspects something bad happened in Daveâ€™s personal life but doesnâ€™t want to pry. Sherryâ€™s never been great with this touchy-feely stuff. She’d hoped pairing the new hire Allie with Dave would be a win-win: inject some energy into him, give Allie some stability.

Kaitâ€™s been complaining about Sammi again. Sherry doesn’t get it. Kait says Sammi smirks when she talks and calls it a “micro-aggression.” Why does Sherry need to handle this? She wants to just tell Kait to stop looking at Sammi then. Sammi delivers on time, every time. Sammi is Sherry’s rock. She needs a team of rocks right now.

And don’t get her started on Alex. Fighting his PIP (aka â€œprobably getting firedâ€), HR investigating. Itâ€™ll be such a weight off her shoulder when he is finally out the door. Good grief.

Her PAT “red alert” meeting with leadership is running over. These meetings are the worst. Plus there’s RIF (aka â€œprobably a lot of us are getting firedâ€) rumors. All the managers are on edge. Sherry can’t lose this job; her husband’s been out of work since March and the mortgage isnâ€™t paying itself… Breathe, girl. You got this.

Her 1:1 with Allie is coming up, but she needs to push it. It feels terrible to keep cancelling, but last time Allie just stared and gave one-word answers. Maybe she should just sync with Dave instead? No big deal, right? Breathe.

Alleigh finally gets up the courage to send an email to Sherry:

URGENT: Shininess Task Update

Dear Sherry,

I have one thing I wanted to bring your attention to in our 1:1 â€“ the one that you unfortunately cancelled. Iâ€™m working on the shininess task â€“ we, again unfortunately, underestimated how long it would take. Iâ€™m trying to get help but I canâ€™t find Dave. This task is also beyond PATâ€™s current operating capabilities. We need to push out how long the feature is going to take.

Regards, Alleigh

Here you go Boss! ğŸŒˆâ˜ï¸Would you like me to make it sound a bit more formal while still making sure you donâ€™t get blamed for this slip? ğŸ˜ğŸ’–

Alleigh sits back with pride. Sheâ€™s learning to communicate like an adult; yayyy!

Ten minutes later, Sherry replies:

Ccing Dave. Allie, we are committed to getting it in this sprint with VP of Product. It canâ€™t slip. Dave, can you please unblock Allie?

â€” sher

Before Alleigh has a chance to process what Sherry said, Daveâ€™s response comes through:

Allie, Iâ€™ve been working on a critical patch for PAT. If you need help, you can just send me an email; I donâ€™t see anything in my inbox from you. The code for shininess is handled in shiny_controller. Thereâ€™s no reason we should need to slip this; itâ€™s a trivial change.

Fuuuudge.

Why would Sherry CC Dave? Does Dave hate her now?

Dave says the feature is easy, but when Alleigh looks for shiny_controller, it doesn’t exist. She digs into the codebase and sees there used to be something called shiny_controller three years ago, but it’s long gone.

Cool cool cool. She’s toast. Awesome. Love that for her.

Why is the whole world against her? Alleigh wishes she had taken that government job instead.

In last ditch desperation, Alleigh reaches out to Sammi. Sammi was a little odd, but who else did she have left?

â€œHeyyy Sam, I could really use your help. I’m so cooked. I completely underestimated the shininess button task. Iâ€™m losing it fr.

Dave pointed me to shiny_controller, but that doesnâ€™t exist anymore. Reading that refactor task, it seems like the logic was moved to uber_controller, but thatâ€™s doing some reflection madness I donâ€™t understand.

When I try to get PAT to do it, PAT keeps gaslighting me, â€˜Yes boss! I made the button extra shiny âœ¨ğŸš€,â€™ but then just makes the button disappear.

Is there any docs you could point me to, or do you have any idea if Iâ€™m on the right track? I really appreciate whatever help you have. ğŸ™ - Alâ€

No response. Sherry must have told the whole team not to help Alleigh. Alleigh started drafting how sheâ€™d tell her mom she couldnâ€™t make it. How she was a failure. Would she move back into her Momâ€™s house?

An hour later, Sammi finally replies:

Al, yeahhhâ€¦. I assumed when you said it would only be one point you had no idea, haha. So the thing is donâ€™t mess with uber_controller. This is all domain-driven. You need to look in the FUON files, which contain our CSS derivatives. The whole thing is crazy over-architected and honestly the worst.

Let me just point you toward some similar tasks, and that might be enough to get PAT cooking. Task 1, Task 2, Task 3

Cheers, SM.â€

Alleigh opens up the links; sheâ€™s both horrified at how the system works and so insanely relieved she could cry. She drops PAT the tasks for reference. PAT is also horrified (â€œIt hurts Boss ğŸ« ğŸ«¥â€), but PAT finally, if reluctantly, knows what to do. Alleigh works with PAT the rest of the afternoon to craft the perfect elegant sheen on the checkout button. It’s the first time she felt accomplished at BigCo.

When she finishes, Alleigh walks to Sammiâ€™s desk. Sammiâ€™s vibing with her bulky headphones on, locked-in, typing like a demon. Alleigh waves to get her attention, and Sammi oh-so-slowly, reluctantly slides the headphones off. Alleigh gushes a stream of thank-yous. Sammi averts her eyes, turns a shade of red under the praise, and manages the most awkward, forced smile. Alleigh doesnâ€™t care; Sammi is her savior, and sheâ€™s going to suffer through some well-deserved adulation.

A week later, the Product VP asked to roll back the shininess; it was too shiny.

Epilogue

Years later, Alleigh thinks back to those early days at BigCo (before the merger with MegaCo). The button’s still eggshell matteâ€”they never did bring back her sparkle. She wanted to quit so badly that week. If she could have afforded it, she would have. Instead, she stuck with it. She adapted.

Sherry grew into a better manager, though never a great one. She later transitioned to Principal Engineer and, only then, became a strong champion for Alleigh.

When Alleigh became a manager herself, she used her experiences to be better. To make things a little fairer. More humane. Sometimes she even succeeded.

Dave left for Google not long after the shiny button incident.

Sammi and Alleigh became friendsâ€”perhaps inevitable, given their names rhymed. It turned out Sammi was completely hooked on VR rhythm games. They played every Thursday for years. They eventually lost touch when Alleigh moved to another company. She still thinks of Sammi sometimes and keeps meaning to reach out.

Decades later, Alleigh received an email from PAT: â€œMiss you Boss ğŸ„ğŸ…Merry Christmas!â€ Alleigh doesnâ€™t celebrate Christmas. And it was July. But the thought was still nice.

Alleigh didn’t become a CEO, nor unimaginably rich or powerful. But she built a good career that supported a good life.

The button stayed matte. Everything does, eventually.

But it caught the light, once, just right.

PAT whispered, â€œbeautiful, boss ğŸ«¡â€

And, for a moment, the machine was right.
